div.div: Getting Started: Obtain an API Key
Follow these steps to get your API key from OpenWeatherMap for use with the Weather API.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Welcome to the Weather & Task API documentation. This API provides two powerful sets of endpoints designed to help developers integrate weather data and task management capabilities into their applications with ease.
The Weather & Task API provides two sets of functionalities

ol.li: A simple /weather endpoint for retrieving real-time weather by city. It’s ideal for apps that need to display live temperature, weather descriptions, or customize content based on location.

A /tasks endpoints offer a full-featured task management system. Developers can:
Create, read, update, and delete tasks (CRUD)
Retrieve paginated task lists
Perform partial updates (PATCH)
Use query parameters for flexible data fetching
Handle rate limits gracefully using standard HTTP headers

div.p: This documentation is your complete guide to integrating and using the Weather & Task API efficiently. Whether you’re building a weather widget or a productivity tool, you’ll find all the examples, parameters, and error handling you need to succeed.

h2.span: Getting Started: Obtain an API Key

div.p: Follow these steps to get your API key from OpenWeatherMap for use with the Weather API.

li.span: Click on Sign in to your account.

div.div: Note: If you don’t have an account, click Create an Account and register.

li.span: Once signed in, click on your profile name in the top menu.
From the dropdown, select My API keys.
You’ll see your existing API keys listed. Do one of the following:
Click Generate to create a new API key. Copy the new API Key.

div.div: Important: These API keys are secret and should not be shared with anyone. Treat them like passwords.

li.span: Optionally, give your API key a name for easy identification.

div.p: Authentication is the process of verifying the identity of a client before granting access to the API.

This API uses an API key to authenticate requests. Including the correct API key in your request headers is required to access protected endpoints. It ensures that only authorized users can use the service and helps track usage per user.
RRefer to the Getting Started (on page ) section to learn how to obtain your API key.

Pagination refers to dividing a large set of results into smaller, manageable chunks or "pages." When fetching data like task lists or weather logs, pagination prevents overloading the client and server with too much data at once. It also helps improve performance and allows users to navigate through data efficiently using page and limit parameters.

li.div:
Use query parameters:
page: Page number (default: 1)
limit: Items per page (default: 10, max: 100)

div.div:
The API enforces rate limiting. It restricts the number of API requests a client can make within a specified time period. To maintain server performance and ensure fair access for all users, this API limits the number of requests based on the user’s subscription level. If the limit is exceeded, the API returns a 429 Too Many Requests error. This helps protect the API from abuse and overload.
Limit: 60 requests per minute.
Headers:
X-RateLimit-Limit: Max requests allowed
X-RateLimit-Remaining: Requests left
Retry-After: Time to wait before retrying after hitting the limit
On exceeding limit: HTTP 429 Too Many Requests

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: The GET /Weather endpoint allows users to retrieve current weather data for any location on Earth. It aggregates real-time data from global and local weather models, satellites, radars, and an extensive network of weather stations. The data is available in multiple formats, including JSON, XML, and HTML.
This endpoint is designed to provide detailed weather information such as temperature, humidity, wind speed and direction, atmospheric pressure, cloud coverage, and visibility.

li.p: Displaying weather information in travel and tourism apps
Powering smart home devices to react to local weather conditions
Building weather widgets or dashboards for websites or mobile apps

section.p: You must have a valid API key. Refer to the Getting Started t (on page )opic for more details.
Ensure your application can make HTTP GET requests.
The /weather endpoint provides real-time weather data using various query parameters such as city name or coordinates. Responses are returned in JSON by default.

li.span: Send a GET request to the following endpoint:
Include your API key using the appid query parameter.
(Optional) Add other query parameters to customize the response:
Execute the request and inspect the response.

section.p: If the request is successful, a 200 OK response is returned with the current weather data.

ul.li: 401 Unauthorized – Invalid or missing API key
429 Too Many Requests – Rate limit exceeded

tr.td: Group of weather parameters (Rain, Snow, Clouds, etc.)
Detailed description of the weather condition
Temperature. Default: Kelvin. Metric: Celsius. Imperial: Fahrenheit
Perceived temperature. Same units as main.temp
Minimum observed temperature. Same units as main.temp
Maximum observed temperature. Same units as main.temp
Wind speed. Default/Metric: m/s, Imperial: mph
Wind gust. Same units as wind.speed
Precipitation in the last hour (mm/h), if available
Snowfall in the last hour (mm/h), if available
Time shift from UTC in seconds

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: The POST /tasks endpoint allows clients to create new tasks in the task management system. This endpoint is publicly accessible and does not require authentication.
A task represents a unit of work, including attributes such as title, description, due date, status, and priority.
Developers can use this endpoint to add tasks dynamically to a user's list or queue.

li.p: They enter task details such as the title, due date, and priority.
The application sends a POST request to /tasks with the task data.

ul.li: The server responds with 201 Created status and the created task details

div.section: The POST /tasks endpoint allows you to create a new task by providing task details in the request body.

li.span: Send a POST request to /tasks endpoint.
li.div: Use JSON format in the request body.

li.span: Include the following fields in your request body:

ul.li: title – The title of the task (required)
due_date – Due date in ISO 8601 format (optional)

priority – An integer from 1 (low) to 5 (high){ "title": "Finish API Documentation", "description": "Complete the POST /tasks section in the Task API doc.", "due_date": "2025-04-25T18:00:00Z", "priority": 3 }

201 Created – Task created successfully{ "id": "a1b2c3d4e5", "title": "Finish API Documentation", "description": "Complete the POST /tasks section in the Task API doc.", "due_date": "2025-04-25T18:00:00Z", "priority": 3, "status": "pending", "created_at": "2025-04-21T14:32:10Z" }
400 Bad Request – Missing or invalid fields

section.p: A successful response returns the complete task object with an assigned ID.

tr.td: Timestamp when the task was created
